official-title.#text:
To protect 10th Amendment rights by providing special standing for State government officials to
			 challenge proposed regulations, and for other purposes.

quote.#text:
The powers not delegated to the United States by the Constitution, nor prohibited by it to the
			 States, are reserved to the States respectively, or to the people.

text.#text: The 10th Amendment to the Constitution of the United States (referred to in this Act as the

The 10th Amendment expressly limits the powers of the Federal Government to those delegated by the
			 Constitution and reaffirms and protects the freedom of the States to
			 exercise those that are not.

The 10th Amendment reflects the opposition of the Founding Fathers to a Federal Government with
			 expansive powers, their intention for the powers of the States to act as a
			 check on those of the Federal Government, and their concern that the
			 Federal Government would attempt to usurp powers intended to remain with
			 the States.

quote.#text:
The powers delegated by the proposed Constitution to the federal government are few and defined.
			 Those which are to remain in the State governments are numerous and
			 indefinite.

text.#text: James Madison, in The Federalist No. 45, wrote,

quote.#text:
The Tenth Amendment was intended to confirm the understanding of the people at the time the
			 Constitution was adopted, that powers not granted to the United States
			 were reserved to the States or to the people.

text.#text: The Supreme Court, in United States v. Sprague, 282 U.S. 716 (1931), noted,

quote.#text:
The Amendment expressly declares the constitutional policy that Congress may not exercise power in
			 a fashion that impairs the States' integrity or their ability to function
			 effectively in a federal system.

text.#text: The Supreme Court, in Fry v. United States, 421 U.S. 542 (1975), also noted,

The Executive departments and agencies of the Federal Government often promulgate regulations
			 contrary to the spirit and letter of the 10th Amendment.

The 10th Amendment assures that the people of the United States, and each sovereign State in the
			 Union of States, have, and have always had, rights that the Federal
			 Government may not usurp.

Congress has the responsibility to safeguard the 10th Amendment and to recognize that it is as
			 vital and valuable today as on the date of its ratification.
